cosmology.name: The Great Wheel
cosmology.description: The default D&D cosmology includes more than two dozen planes. The most common understanding visualizes them as a group of concentric wheels, with the material realms at the center. The Inner Planes form a wheel around the Material Plane, enveloped in the Ethereal Plane. Then the Outer Planes form another wheel around that one, arranged according to alignment, with the Outlands linking them all.

alternateConfigurations.name: World Tree
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes situated among the roots and branches of a great cosmic tree (literally or figuratively)

alternateConfigurations.name: Vertical Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Material realms suspended between two other realities: the astral realms (the Astral Plane and the Outer Planes) above and the elemental realms (the Inner Planes) below

alternateConfigurations.name: Simplified Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: A cosmology with fewer planes: a Material Plane; the Transitive Planes; a single undifferentiated Elemental Plane; an Overheaven where good deities and Celestials dwell; and an Underworld where evil deities and Fiends reside

alternateConfigurations.name: Orbital Cosmology
alternateConfigurations.description: Planes arranged in a complex system of orbits, with planes exerting greater influence on the Material Plane the closer they draw to it

planeCategories.name: Material Realms
planeCategories.description: Most D&D worlds are located on the Material Plane, which has two planar echoes: the Feywild and the Shadowfell.

planeCategories.name: Transitive Planes
planeCategories.description: The Ethereal Plane and the Astral Plane are boundless realms that provide passage between other planes of existence.

planeCategories.name: Inner Planes
planeCategories.description: The four Elemental Planes (Air, Earth, Fire, and Water), plus the Para-elemental Planes between them, are the Inner Planes.

planeCategories.name: Outer Planes
planeCategories.description: Seventeen Outer Planes correspond to the nine alignments and shades of philosophical difference between them.

planeCategories.name: Positive and Negative Planes
planeCategories.description: These two planes enfold the rest of the cosmology, providing the raw forces of life and death that underlie all existence in the multiverse.

planes.name: Para-elemental Plane of Ooze
planes.philosophicalEssence: The Plane of Ooze heightens the contrast between stable, rigid earth and steadily flowing water. It represents the interaction and sometimes the contrast between the forces and ideals embodied by its constituent elements.

physicalProperties.shape: An endless horrid swamp with no solid earth underlying the muck
physicalProperties.atmosphereNotes: Swampy atmosphere with stinging vines and monstrous swarms of mosquitoes

temperature.description: A swampy environment at the border between the Plane of Water and the Plane of Earth

physicalProperties.dominantElement: Ooze (Earth and Water combined into muck and slime)
physicalProperties.weatherPatterns: Stagnant swamp conditions with dense muck and slime

timeFlow.description: No specific time flow rules documented for this plane

hazards.name: Bottomless Muck
hazards.description: No solid earth underlies the muck of the Plane of Ooze. Structures built on poles stuck in the mud eventually sink. Even settlements consisting of wooden structures suspended above the muck on platforms between trees are the only viable habitations.

gravityModel.description: Normal gravity but no solid ground underlies the muck; all structures eventually sink

hazards.name: Swamp of Oblivion Object Consumption
hazards.description: It is said that any object cast into the Swamp of Oblivion can't be found again for at least a century. Now and then, a desperate soul casts an Artifact of power into this place, keeping it away from the rest of the multiverse for a time.

hazards.name: Monstrous Insects and Hags
hazards.description: Monstrous swarms of mosquitoes infest the stagnant lakes and pools. Hags also inhabit the swamp. The promise of powerful magic lures adventurers to brave the monstrous insects and hags of the swamp.

planarConnections.name: Silt Flats (border with Plane of Water)
planarConnections.description: The region of the Plane of Water nearest to the Para-elemental Plane of Ooze is called the Silt Flats. The water is thick with soil and sludge, turning into muddy ground before giving way to the great swamp that is the Para-elemental Plane.

planarConnections.name: Mud Hills (border with Plane of Earth)
planarConnections.description: The Mud Hills abut the swampy Para-elemental Plane of Ooze. Landslides wear away the slopes of the hills, sending cascades of earth and stone into the bottomless swamp. The Plane of Earth constantly regenerates the land, pushing new hills up as the old ones erode to nothing.
hazards: Cascades of earth and stone into the bottomless swamp

civilizations.name: Swamp Settlements
civilizations.description: The few settlements here consist of wooden structures suspended above the muck on platforms between trees. Visitors to the plane have sometimes tried elevating houses on poles stuck in the mud, but since no solid earth underlies the muck, even such structures eventually sink.
civilizations.location: Suspended on platforms between gnarled trees

specialRules.name: Oblivion of Lost Objects
specialRules.description: Any object cast into the Swamp of Oblivion can't be found again for at least a century. Desperate souls sometimes cast Artifacts of power into this place, keeping them away from the rest of the multiverse for a time.
specialRules.mechanicalEffect: Objects cast into the plane cannot be found for at least 100 years. This makes the plane a repository for hidden Artifacts and powerful magic items that parties may seek to recover.

adventureThemes: Seeking powerful Artifacts cast into the swamp to be hidden from the multiverse
Exploring the contrast between stable earth and flowing water
Survival in an environment with no solid ground

crossReferences.description: Elemental Plane of Water section references the Silt Flats border region with the Para-elemental Plane of Ooze
Elemental Plane of Earth section references the Mud Hills border region with the Para-elemental Plane of Ooze
Ethereal Curtains table lists Plane of Ooze as entry 12 with Chocolate colored curtain
Inner Planes general description covers inhabitants and structure of elemental and para-elemental planes

planarTravelMethods.name: Ethereal Curtain to Para-elemental Plane of Ooze
planarTravelMethods.description: In the Deep Ethereal, curtains of vaporous color lead to the Border Ethereal connected to the Para-elemental Plane of Ooze. The curtain leading to the Plane of Ooze is Chocolate colored.
requirements: Access to the Deep Ethereal via Plane Shift, Gate, or magical portal
risks: Ether cyclones in the Deep Ethereal
Travel time of 1d10 × 10 hours between curtains

planarTravelMethods.name: Planar Portal to Para-elemental Plane of Ooze
planarTravelMethods.description: Portals can connect to the Para-elemental Plane of Ooze. Vortices joining the plane with similar locations on the Material Plane (such as vast swamps or bogs) may exist.
requirements: Finding a portal that leads to the Plane of Ooze

planarTravelMethods.name: Spell Travel to Para-elemental Plane of Ooze
planarTravelMethods.description: Spells such as Gate and Plane Shift can directly transport adventurers to the Para-elemental Plane of Ooze. Etherealness allows entry to the Ethereal Plane from which the Plane of Ooze can be reached via curtains.
requirements: Appropriate spell slot and spell known
Tuning fork attuned to the Plane of Ooze for Plane Shift
risks: Arriving in the hostile swamp environment

savingThrowProbabilities.formula: P(fail | modifier m) = max(0.05, min(0.95, (DC - 1 - m) / 20))
